description: From Middle English rosten, a borrowing from Old French rostir (“to roast, to torture with fire”), from Frankish *rōstijan (“to roast, broil”), from Proto-Germanic *raustijaną (“to roast”), from Proto-Indo-European *rews- (“to crackle; roast”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian rosterje (“to roast”), Dutch roosten, roosteren (“to roast”), German rösten (“to roast”).

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Subjected to roasting; bantered; severely criticized.
A cut of meat suited to roasting; meat that has been roasted.
examples: Serve the roast with gravy and mashed potatoes.

entries.meaning: A meal consisting of roast foods.
examples: Come over this weekend for Sunday roast.

entries.meaning: The degree to which something, especially coffee, is roasted.
examples: Dark roast means that the coffee bean has been roasted to a higher temperature and for a longer period of time than in light roast.

entries.meaning: An instance of being severely admonished, criticized, roasted. [from 18th century]
A comical event, originally fraternal, where a person is subjected to verbal attack, yet may be praised by sarcasm and jokes.
(Canada, US) A social event at which food is roasted and eaten. [from 19th century]
examples: On Memorial Day we hosted a wiener roast in the backyard.

entries.meaning: (slang) A creative insult as a response to something someone said.

verbs.description: roast (third-person singular simple present roasts, present participle roasting, simple past and past participle roasted)

entries.meaning: (transitive or intransitive or ergative) To cook food by heating in an oven or over a fire without covering, resulting in a crisp, possibly even slightly charred appearance.
examples: Coordinate terms: bake, boil, broil, fry, grill, poach, toast
to roast meat on a spit

entries.meaning: To cook by surrounding with hot embers, ashes, sand, etc.
examples: to roast a potato in ashes

entries.meaning: (transitive or intransitive or ergative) To process by drying through exposure to sun or artificial heat.
examples: Coffee beans need roasting before use.

entries.meaning: To heat to excess; to heat violently; to burn.

examples: I'm late home for the fourth time this week; my mate will really roast me this time.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To subject to bantering, severely criticize, sometimes as a comedy routine.
examples: The class clown enjoys being roasted by mates as well as staff.

entries.meaning: (metalworking) To dissipate the volatile parts of by heat, as ores.
